page.title: 11THE CHANGING SHAPE
page.content: THIS EXPOSED STRETCH OF COASTLINE IS CONSTANTLY UNDER ATTACK FROM THE WIND AND SEA. CONSEQUENTLY THE SHAPE OF THIS COAST HAS CHANGED MANY TIMES IN THE RECENT PAST, GENERALLY GRADUAL BUT OFTEN DRAMATICALLY. DURING THE NINETEENTH CENTURY THERE WAS ABOUT 220 METRES ADDED TO THE COAST OFF FORMBY POINT. HOWEVER, SINCE 1906 THERE HAS BEEN A LOSS OF 400 METRES IN PLACES. THE PLANTING OF MARRAM GRASS IS STILL THE MAIN METHOD OF STOPPING EROSION, ALTHOUGH BRUSHWOOD AND SYNTHETIC FENCES ARE BEING PUT UP TO TRY TO REGAIN SOME OF THE RECENT LOSSES. THIS AREA IS PART OF THE SEFTON COAST MANAGEMENT SCHEME WHERE SEVERAL BODIES CO-OPERATE TO PRESERVE THIS IMPORTANT COASTLINE.
